statement: As someone who works in business and believes in free markets, I think tech companies have a right to make money, but they also have a responsibility to be honest and straightforward about what data they collect and how they use it. Users should clearly know what they’re agreeing to, have real options to opt out, and be protected from their information being sold or misused without their consent. I don’t want heavy-handed government control, but I do support reasonable rules that hold companies accountable when they cross the line. In my view, respecting people’s privacy is part of basic integrity, just like treating customers fairly in any other business.

statement: As someone who’s lived long enough to see the world go from paper charts to smartphones, I believe tech companies have a moral duty to treat our personal data like a patient’s medical file: private, protected, and never used without clear, informed consent. If they profit from our information, we should know exactly how, have the power to opt out, and see strong laws in place to stop abuse—especially for older people and others who may be more vulnerable.

statement: I think tech companies should have to be super clear about what data they collect and exactly how they use it, in normal language that kids and parents can actually understand. Since they make money off our info, they should protect it like it’s something valuable we’re lending them, not something they own. They also shouldn’t be allowed to track or target kids without strict limits and real permission from parents, because that feels creepy and unfair.
